11:20 am
PM

So Bryce, what's your take on the Scottish situation?

PM

I had mentioned the other day that Morgan Stanley were looking at Glasgow for a move

PM

But that's all gone quiet

11:21 am
BE

The legal basis for Scotland inheriting Britain's EU membership doesn't seem to exist, according to people who are paid more than me to know about stuff.

PM

hmm

BE

So, yeah, I guess the boom in the Glasgow banking quarter is on hold for now.

11:21 am
PM

Let me share some Malcolm Barr

PM

JPM

PM

Always good on this sort of stuff

11:22 am
PM

While the UK as a whole voted to leave the EU, Scotland voted 62%-38% to remain.

Opinion polls released since the referendum result suggest both that support for a new referendum has moved above 50%, as has support for Scottish independence. Given the vagaries of polling of late, the reported levels of support should not be taken too seriously. But the direction of movement is clear. The SNP is currently the dominant force in Scottish politics, despite not having a majority in the Scottish Parliament. Their control over mechanisms of representation in Scotland makes it near certain they will be at the table as the EU negotiation process takes place. And that process is likely to provide ample opportunity for the SNP to highlight changes in the relationship with the EU being driven by Westminster, against their will. It seems likely to us that support for Scottish independence and a new referendum will build.

PM

The incoming PM at Westminster is likely to resist calls for a new referendum on Scottish independence in the first instance, in the hope that such calls will diminish and other political issues emerge which overtake the independence debate in Scotland. Our sense, however, is that ongoing resistance in Westminster to a referendum will simply cause support for a referendum in Scotland to build. It is extremely difficult to gauge when those pressures will generate a new referendum, but our guess is that one will be held shortly before the UK leaves the EU, likely in late 2019. The choice will hence be between Scottish independence and a future membership of the EU, versus remaining within the United Kingdom.

PM

At the last referendum the corporate sector, politicians from elsewhere in the UK, and those from elsewhere largely backed the idea of Scotland remaining within the UK. Our sense is that the group arguing for Scotland to stay will be more narrowly based the next time around, and Scotland will vote for Independence.

11:22 am
PM

So, Barr thinks it will happen

PM

Here's some more

PM

Choosing between the UK and the EU
Head of the SNP and First Minister Sturgeon has been investigating options for Scotland to remain part of the EU while the remainder of the UK leaves. We find it difficult to believe that this can progress very far. As we understand it, the legal relationship is between the EU and the United Kingdom, with the latter as a single entity. And ultimately we do not believe that a lack of assent from the Scottish Parliament to EU exit would prevent the exit from the EU by the UK as a whole. Hence if Scotland is to acquire EU membership in its own right, it will need to become a fully independent state and apply. And if it is clear that remaining within the EU is among the key motivations for Scottish independence, it is reasonable to argue that the referendum on independence should occur before the UK as a whole leaves the EU, so that some attempt to establish continuity in the arrangements for Scotland can be made.

11:23 am
PM

During the Scottish independence referendum campaign of 2014, the EU made it clear that a new Scottish state would need to go through the usual procedures for a new state to join the EU if it wished to do so. That process is summarized in the appendix below. It is typically thought to take 5-7 years, and at several points in the process unanimity among the existing member states is required to proceed. Given that Scotland was previously in the EU, establishing the necessary convergence in the required 35 policy areas might be accelerated relative to the usual 5-7 year timeframe. But the signal being sent from the rest of the EU last time around was that Scotland joining the would not be an accelerated process, given that a number of countries (Spain is the most conspicuous) were and still are struggling to manage regional pressures of their own. In the wake of the rest of the UK’s decision to leave the EU, however, we expect the EU’s position to soften.

PM

Though difficult issues will remain to be dealt with, we expect the EU to signal that the process will be accelerated as much as possible should Scotland become independent and wish to join. A key issue will be establishing the currency arrangements – we discuss that below. But subject to agreement on the currency and other issues being found, we could envisage a bilateral agreement between a newly independent Scotland and the rest of the EU which sought to afford some of the benefits of EU membership during the interregnum between independence and full membership of the EU. For example, we would expect a newly independent Scotland to be afforded access to the EU’s single market on terms similar to those adopted by the rest of the UK, and for free movement of individuals between the EU and Scotland to be retained. A by-product, however, would be the need for a ‘hard’ border between England and Scotland, so that flows of individuals between the two nations could be controlled.

PM

Sorry, this is a bit long

11:23 am
PM

But useful i think

PM

All countries joining the EU since Maastricht have a treaty obligation to join the euro at some point. In the Scottish case, we would expect the same. But this legal requirement does not come with any predetermined timescale. Sweden, for example, is subject to this commitment but has made it clear that it will only make moves toward euro adoption when they see fit. Through this mechanism Scotland could avoid being forced to adopt the Euro and the single monetary policy that comes with it for many years. However, it is highly unlikely that Scotland would be able to continue to use the pound sterling as its currency on an ongoing basis. As an independent country it would have no claim on influencing the Bank of England’s monetary policy, and no access to a stock of sterling reserves large enough to underpin a lender of last resort facility for its financial sector. As a result, independence would likely come with the need to create a new currency for Scotland, and an independent monetary policy. That raises big challenges of implementation. But given at least some shared interest both in England and the rest of the EU, in establishing stability in Scotland post independence (it would still be a big market for English firms) we could imagine a framework where both the ECB and the Bank of England made some small portion of their reserves available to assist in the management of the new currency upon its launch. Hence for example, there could be an initial commitment to try and stabilize the new currency near parity to the pound, with interest rates set by a Scottish central bank above those set by the Bank of England.

PM

The lower price of oil, the likelihood of a “hard” border with England, and the need to implement a new currency are all issues those campaigning for Scottish independence will need to address. It is perhaps a recognition of these issues, alongside voter fatigue after recent referenda, that has moderated the SNP’s calls for a new referendum on independence thus far (the SNP has said it should be “on the table” rather than pushing for a specific timeframe). But we expect the recognition among Scots of a need to make difficult choice to grow over time. To remain part of a UK which is out of the EU and where the divergence between the politics of Westminster and Edinburgh is increasingly clear. Or to endure the uncertainties associated with creating a new sovereign state with its own currency, but with eventual promise of greater self-determination including the ability to remain a full member of the EU. Our base case is they ultimately choose the latter.

PM

Tad stressed this end

11:29 am
BE

Commodity markets are in reasonable shape. The Chinese steel industry gross margins has normalised around USD250/t, down from the USD300/t surge in April, but above the sub USD200/t seen at the end of 2015, indicating an industry that is at least treading water. As spare capacity restarted in May, net exports did not grow, indicating apparent demand/restocking has been relatively robust. Post the speculative surge in April, the physical iron ore market is clearing at USD50/t and we raise our 2016 forecast from USD45/t to USD50/t to reflect this. Exchange inventory movements indicate that the physical refined copper market looks broadly in balance – there does appear to be a well-supplied concentrate market (TC/RC’s greater than 100/10) and some excess cathode now in the Asian market, but LME prices of USD4800/t are relatively low (relative to costs and history) and under the prices discounted in M&A transactions. China remains structurally short high quality iron and copper resources, and we think this will underpin prices.

BE

Stocks: We upgrade our ratings on BHP Billiton, Antofagasta and Glencore from Neutral to Buy and upgrade our rating on Anglo American from Sell to Neutral. We have been looking for a sell-off in the miners to become more constructive. The FTSE100 market has differentiated between UK/non-UK stocks in absolute sterling terms post the Brexit vote, although we argue this could eventually go further once a weaker sterling is taken into account for sectors such as mining which are neither sterling nor UK sectors. Our FV changes can be found in Figure 1. In addition to this, our revisions put us slightly ahead of consensus on the top line (consensus still has downside to spot/forwards), and we are notably ahead on EBITDA particularly for BHP and RIO, but we see these as stocks where productivity and cost gains are going to surprise on the upside. We remain constructive on the sector in the longer term due to contracting capex, continued structural demand growth, better capital management policies and lower costs, and see room for more generalist underweight covering.

BE

So ....

11:31 am
undefined
PM

There's more knife catching from the sell side

PM

UBS have a ten opportunities thing

11:32 am
BE

The difference between top-down and bottom-up analysis right now really is striking.

PM

This is broad, geographic stuff

PM

Buy US equities
Move since referendum result: -4%
Forecast upside by year end: +5-8%
The US has limited direct export exposure to the UK (3%). US companies generate about two-thirds of their revenues
domestically and should benefit from the strength of the US consumer. Solid labor income and the ongoing
improvement in the housing market should support consumption, and the Federal Reserve is likely to keep policy
relatively loose, so company refinancing costs should remain low. We will monitor US dollar strength, but, on
balance, we see the fall in US equities as an opportunity, and remain overweight them in our global tactical asset
allocation. We particularly favor stocks executing buybacks and/or paying healthy dividends.

11:33 am
PM

Buy dividend stocks
Europe:
Move since referendum result: -1% vs Eurozone equities
Forecast upside by year end: +5% vs Eurozone equities
Stocks across Europe were hit by the UK's vote to leave the EU, including more defensive stocks that pay dividends.
The 12-month-forward dividend yield on the MSCI EMU index is now 4%, 3.9% higher than German government
bonds and close to an all-time high. We think that companies able to grow dividends should offer better total returns
than the overall Eurozone equity market.

PM

APAC:
Move since referendum result: -2%
Forecast upside by year end: +5-8%
APAC growth is only marginally affected by Brexit, and Asian equities are relatively cheap at present. Stocks with
bond-like characteristics – high yields, low earnings growth risk, and strong free-cash flow – can perform well in an
uncertain environment, in our view. We focus on high-dividend stocks in markets with the lowest government bond
yields: Hong Kong, Singapore, China and Thailand.

PM

Oh, this is at least closer to home

11:33 am
PM

Buy UK real estate vs European real estate stocks
Move since referendum result: -19% for UK vs -3.5% for Europe ex-UK
Forecast upside by year end: Low double digit total return
UK real estate stocks have priced in a horror scenario. Values look close to historical extremes: spreads are close to
historic high, and stock price implies a 25% discount to asset value. And there are a number of factors that might
mitigate the impact of UK leaving the EU: (1) exposure to financial tenants is low, (2) sterling declines would make
pricing more attractive for international buyers, (3) BoE will likely cut rates, (4) Brexit might reduce the appetite for
speculative office development and limit future supply, and (5) leverage levels are low. Although we see upside to
year-end, continuing uncertainties mean investors should be prepared to hold for 1.5 – 2 years if necessary.

PM

Sorry about the formatting

PM

Contact UBS for the rest

11:45 am
BE

Here's Morgan Stanley on the banks.

BE

Negative RBS and Clydesdale.

BE

Our framework: we view this seismic shock as one of earnings and
heightened uncertainty, but not systemic – though we can't rule out tail
risks. UK banks have greater than 3x the capital ratios of 2007, dramatically better funding
positions and were prepared. But weaker outlook will aggravate those banks
with capital gaps, complex restructurings & high Texas ratios (Italians pivotal).

11:46 am
BE

Still prefer banks with stronger capital bases/more resilient earnings –
KBC, ABN, and Lloyds at today's price. Banks with robust capital positions
and superior ROE should be better able to withstand any growth shocks and
hold flattish divi expectations and be relative outperformers.

BE

Prefer banks with more resilient international earnings & less at risk of
even more negative rates. We are concerned that not only will
lending/trading/commissions be weaker, but a worse rates outlook will be a
big hit on both UK but also eurozone banks, as the ECB may reopen what
we've called the "dangerous experiment" of negative rates – German &
Peripheral banks hit hardest. We reflect this risk in lower EPS. We downgrade
RBS to EW and Clydesdale to UW. We upgrade Baer and Schroders to OW;
downgrade Commerzbank to UW; Henderson to EW.

BE

More cautious on Peripherals, especially in Italy where the risk of
intervention is material, and those banks with highest Texas ratios in
particular (UW Monte dei Paschi, Popolare, Greeks). We take Intesa out of our
most preferred list, and are intensely focused on Italian TARP initiatives.

11:46 am
BE

Understandably cautious on banks with material capital gaps to new
regulatory standards by 2019, which will need to respond. Deutsche still
has the biggest gap to new standards (€8-9bn by 2019) on our base case, but
CS (which had hoped to close the gap through its Swiss sub-IPO) and
UniCredit also stand out.
What's in the price? Domestic UK and eurozone banks now trade on 0.59x
P/B, implying a ~6.6% medium-term ROE using a ~10.5% COE vs our revised
expectation of ~7.6% in 2017 and 8.1% in 2018. Clearly, though, the market
and we are weighed down by tail risks, uncertainty and capital gaps.
Most preferred: Lloyds, Danske, ABN, KBC, BNP. We add Julius Baer, take out
Intesa. Least preferred: Standard Chartered, Clydesdale, Commerzbank, SHB.
We remove HSBC and Aberdeen.

PM

Texas ratio are bad debts, no?

PM

ah yes

11:47 am
PM

The Texas ratio takes the amount of a bank's non-performing assets and loans, as well as loans delinquent for more than 90 days, and divides this number by the firm's tangible capital equity plus its loan loss reserve. A ratio of more than 100 (or 1:1) is considered a warning sign.

BE

I wish I knew more about bank financing, though not enough to actually read about bank financing.

BE

Here's the relevant chart there.

11:48 am
BE

BE

So back to the top. Forecasts do this .....

BE

For the UK banks we cut our 2018 EPS forecasts by 12-27%. Within this, we reduce our Lloyds and Barclays forecasts by 18% and 12%, respectively, in line with our earlier indication of 10-20%; for RBS, the net profit impact is higher (27%) owing to higher operating leverage. We cut our domestic UK bank revenue forecasts by 4-7%, with net interest income under pressure due to (1) slower loan growth as demand wilts, investment decisions are put off and collateral values come under pressure; and (2) weaker net interest margins due to lower-for-longer rates and (somewhat) higher funding costs. We expect lower activity levels after the initial volatility to reduce fee income / investment banking revenues too. Cost cutting will remain in focus to cushion the impact on profits, but significant work is already being done and an exit from the EU will necessarily imply certain costs rising (particularly for wholesale banks). We expect only a moderate tick up in impairment as lower rates ease the burden of debt servicing.

11:49 am
BE

And valuations are this.

BE

Domestic UK and eurozone banks are trading on 0.59x, implying a ~6.6% medium-term ROE using a ~10.5% cost of equity versus our revised expectation of ~7.6% in 2017 and 8.1% in 2018. Clearly, tail risks, uncertainty and capital gaps are weighing on investor expectations.

PM

Sure are

11:29 am
BE

UK listings of global mining stocks should benefit more from sterling weakness than the impact on commodity prices, which are driven more by growth elsewhere. We adjust our fair values for sterling weakness and an adjustment in our commodity price forecasts, and upgrade BLT, ANTO and GLEN to Buy (from Neutral) and AAL to Neutral. Critical to this is our view that underlying commodity markets are OK at present – and this note focuses on short-term Chinese commodity indicators (trade, inventory trends, arbitrage levels) to see what the markets are telling us about short-term demand.
Sometimes it’s good to be irrelevant. The UK mining sector naturally has little to do with issues in the UK or the Eurozone – it remains a USD denominated industry, producing largely in South Africa, Australia, Brazil and Chile and selling to Asia. We don’t wish to be flippant, and threats to European growth will affect commodity demand, it is just that commodity markets have already repriced to reflect a slowing China. We think miners in general should reprice higher in response to sterling weakness.
